entries.title: Typography Tokens
entries.body: Typography is one of the more deceptively complex elements in a design system. While we often talk about them as existing at the lowest level of our systems, they are in fact made up of an even more ganular set of tokens for attributes like font family, weight, size, etc. Each of the individual styles in this system, for example, are built from one of 3 families, 4 weights, 14 sizes, 5 amounts of leading, and 3 amounts of tracking.

img.alt: Documentation for the type styles from a recently completed design system.

entries.title: Look Back: Illustration
entries.body: Although it has been a smaller part of my workload recently, there was a time when being an illustrator was a big part of my identity as a designer. Gig posters were some of the first visual works that I remember getting excited about as a kid, so it feels like a natural progression that I would eventually design and print them myself.

img.alt: A grid of poster and illustrations completed over the course of several years.

entries.title: Semantic V. Primitive
entries.body: Semantic v. Primitive. If you've read through Figma's Variables playground file, you saw these two terms a lot. But in my opinion, they were never clearly defined. Here's my take: the difference between primitive and semantic design tokens is as simple as the difference between What and How. Primitive tokens define a literal attribute (what something is) where semantic tokens describe an intended function (how something should be used).

img.alt: An explanation of the distinction between semantic and primitive design tokens.

entries.title: Generative Sketches
entries.body: As it turns out, math is fun. I wish someone had told me in school that you can use trig to create pretty pictures. I would have been way more interested. These are a couple of simple sketches I made on a plane ride from Seattle to Jacksonville. Whether it's basic addition, subtraction, and division, probabilities, or the undulations of waveforms, Math is the engine that drives everything in these compositions, from motion to color distribution.

entries.title: AI Music Recommendations
entries.body: I've been playing around with and building interfaces on top of LLMs for the past several weeks. This is a basic proof of concept leveraging Spotify and Open AI's APIs to offer music recommendations based on a user-provided artist. Surprisingly, its recommendations are generally pretty good and it only infrequently makes up artists who don't exist—which I can usually catch by cross-checking results with Spotify. Now that I've got the basic functionality worked out, I want to further push and develop the UX/UI into something more interesting and delightful.

entries.title: Amazon Devices Icons
entries.body: Throughout my time at Turnstyle, I have drawn—or managed the drawing of—over a 1,000 icons for the Amazon Devices design group. During my first year with the agency, the Amazon team engaged us to redefine and redraw their icon system from the ground up. Since then we've continued to expand the set as needed, month-by-month, icon-by-icon. One of my parting gifts to the Turnstyle team was an internal web app for browsing and downloading icons from the set to hopefully make managing the project easier moving forward.

img.alt: A web repository for the Amazon Decives icon set

entries.title: Vulcan Real Estate Launch
entries.body: The new Vulcan Real Estate brand and website officially launched earlier this weekand I couldn't be more excited for Josh, Deron, and the rest of the Vulcan team. They were a joy to collaborate with over the past year-and-change and worked diligently to shepherd this project through to completion.

entries.title: Portfolio 2020
entries.body: Today, I officially switched my domain over to the website you're seeing now. I'm posting this in memory of the previous version of my portfolio. It wasn't much, but I do really enjoy the op-art eyeball animation I managed to pull off with a simple SVG and GSAP. RIP, little buddy. You were here for a good time and, to be honest, a longer time than I intended.

entries.title: Teague Website 2023
entries.body: Last week, we relaunched the website for our friends over at Teague, one of the coolest design consultancies in the biz. This was an interesting project because it was more evolution then revolution. We launched a previous version of their site 4+ years ago. Rather than throwing that work out and starting over, We spent much of our time rethinking and reimaging our original designs to make them more streamlined, resilient, and flexible.

entries.title: Squiggler App
entries.body: This personal project began as conversation with a coworker about a tool we wish we had for a branding project. We wanted a way to generatively create SVG squiggles that we could manipulate across different axes like sharpness, flow, size, etc. Developing it required a lot of mind-bending research into the technical details of how SVG paths are drawn and the math behind sin waves, but the result is a simple and easy-to-use single-purpose app.

entries.title: AllStock Figma Plugin
entries.body: I have always found it frustrating that if you want to look for a stock image without leaving Figma, you have to choose a plugin specific to a single stock image resource. AllStock is a one-stop shop for finding and using high-quality images inside of your Figma projects, allowing you to browse popular free libraries like Unsplash, Pexels, and Pixabay all at the same time. Built with Svelte, Tailwind, and Typescript.

img.alt: Promo image for a Figma plugin that searches stock image sites like Unsplash, Pexels, and Pixabay.

entries.title: Carbon Direct Navigation
entries.body: For the team modal on Carbon Direct's sites, we wanted to leverage the best parts of single- and multi-page app experiences. When a team member's card is clicked, we intercept the navigation, update the URL bar, and open a modal displaying their profile without reloading the page. When the modal is closed, the previous URL is restored and, because we never left the page, we're able to seamlessly return the user to the exact spot they left off.

entries.title: GLY Page Transitions
entries.body: I've personally trended towards simpler, quicker page transitions recently, but the ones on GLY's site are one of the features that people comment on most. I think it's the quick pop of color you get as the page animates off combined with the fact that the entrance animations happen relatively quickly.

entries.title: Get Some Ipsum Figma Plugin
entries.body: This is my first Figma plugin—a simple, flexible lorem ipsum generator. It smoothes out some of the issues I have with other, similar plugins. Specifically, it runs through a bunch of custom logic before outputting the result to make sure that you end up with ipsum that look more like proper sentences (insofar as a dead language can look like English).

img.alt: Mobile screenshots of the GLY website

entries.title: GLY Web Mobile
entries.body: There's always a handful of modules where the responsive design approach isn't immediately obvious. Take the 'Constructive Optimism' component for example—you have a circle centered inside a div that in turn has text centered inside of it. Part of what makes it visually interesting is having two sides of the circle cropped off the screen at all times. It took a bit of wrangling to make sure that we were always cropping either the top and bottom or left and right, depending on the screen size.
